awd_titl_txt: Multiparameter Harmonic analysis and sharp geometric inequalities with applications to PDEs
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract (Lu, 1301595)

The proposed research project includes solving problems in two main directions: sharp geometric inequalities and multiparameter harmonic analysis. Recent developments in the area of sharp geometric inequalities include best constants for Moser-Trudinger inequalities on the entire Heisenberg group and more general Carnot groups and Adams inequalities on high order Sobolev spaces on unbounded domains in Euclidean spaces. These are circumstances where symmetrization properties do not hold. The PI, in collaboration with his PhD students, have very recently succeeded in developing a rearrangement-free argument. This new method suggests that such sharp geometric inequalities can be established in more general scenarios including Riemannian and sub-Riemannian manifolds.  Moreover, the PI will investigate the existence of extremal functions for these sharp geometric inequalities where many challenging problems still remain open.  Another main direction of research is to develop multiparameter harmonic analysis function space theory in several complicated but important multiparameter settings. The PI, in collaboration with others, has developed a satisfactory theory of discrete Littlewood-Paley square functions in a number of multiparameter scenarios. However,  there are still many other important multiparameter settings where such a discrete Littlewood-Paley theory is yet to be established. 

Multi parameter Harmonic analysis and nonlinear partial differential equations are central areas of modern mathematics. Findings and new tools discovered in this project may lead to new development in the area of classical harmonic analysis, partial differential equations as well as other branches of mathematics. They have many applications in sciences and engineering. The solution to the proposed project will have impact on many other disciplines, including mechanics engineering (such as vibration and noise reduction for vehicles), imaging processing and pattern recognitions in medical sciences, stochastic control and optimization, game theory, chemical combustion, human vision and other topics in the life and medical sciences. Moreover, this project has a substantial training and educational component. It finely integrates research together with education. Many graduate students will actively participate in this project by receiving research training under the supervision of the principal investigator.

por.por_cntn:
Projects completed solved several problems in classical multi-parameter harmonic analysis and optimal geometric inequalities with applications. These include: the boundedness of multi-parameter and multilinear Fourier multipliers with limited smoothness; the boundeness of multi-parameter and bilinear Hilbert transform; flag Hardy spaces and endpoint estimates for the Marcinkiewitz multipliers on the Heisenberg group; multi-parameter Triebel-Lizorkin spaces associated with the composition of two singular integral operators with different homogeneity; boundedness of multi-parameter and multilinear pseudo-differential operators and Fourier integral operators;   best constants for geometric inequalities of Moser-Trudinger and Adams type and their applications to nonlinear partial differential equations with nonlinearity of exponential growth; symmetrization-free methods to establish sharp inequalities in a variety of geometric settings (e.g., higher order Sobolev spaces on Euclidean space, Riemannian manifolds, Sub-Riemannian manifolds); etc.  These problems are important in both analysis, partial differential equations and geometry. The PI has collaborated with his graduate students, post-doctors and young mathematicians including mathematicians in under-represented groups. Students have had the opportunity to present their research findings at conferences. Completion of the projects has contributed to the advancement of these research areas and  the integration of research and education and the training of Ph.D students. Projcts finished and methods developed here will have important impact on further development in the direction of Fourier and harmonic analysis, geometric analysis, partial differential equations, calculus of variations and geometry. Findings and new tools discovered in this project will lead to some new development in these areas as well as other branches of mathematics. Nevertheless, there are still many challenging problems that remain open in this direction and require our further investigation.

Discoveries in the projects carried out by the PI, his students and collaborators can also be helpful to the understanding of phenomenon arising in other disciplines including engineering, life and medical sciences, etc.

The PI and his students have made many presentations on findings in the sponsored project at special sessions of the American Mathematical Society, and other national and international conferences in harmonic analysis and partial differential equations. In particular, studnets were invited to give talks at many occasions. This has helped to disseminate the new discovery into a wide community. Moreover, this project has a substantial training and educational component. Students (including one female student) actively participated in this project by receiving research training under the supervision of the principal investigator. Students were financially supported partly in the summer by this grant and they were also supported partly to attend professional meetings. Through such participation and presentations of conferences, students have the opportunities to share new ideas and thoughts and interact with other well established mathematicians in the areas. These also provide opportunities for the students to become strong young mathematicians and to make better contributions to the society after their graduation. The PI and his students and other colloaborators have completed and published in high quality journals many joint research papers during this period.
